questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the most common primary malignant brain tumor in children?
questions.explanation: Most common primary malignant brain tumor in children is medulloblastoma.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 6-year-old child is brought with complaints of unsteadiness and gait disturbance. On 
neurological examination, nystagmus, areflexia, and hypotonia are noted. Contrast-enhanced 
MRI of the brain shows enhancing nodule within the wall of a cystic mass. The mass is 
resected and histology shows the given finding. Which of the following statements is incorrect 
regarding this tumor?

options.a: BRAF mutation is seen in this tumor
options.d: It belongs to WHO grade II tumors

questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and the image showing Rosenthal fibers is diagnostic of pilocytic 
astrocytoma. It belongs to WHO grade I tumors. Pilocytic astrocytoma typically occurs in children and young adults and is usually located in the 
cerebellum. It is usually a slow-growing tumor and if it occurs in the cerebellum, it can be 
resected. If it extends into the hypothalamic region from the optic tract, it can have a more 
ominous clinical course because of its location. It is often cystic, if solid, it may be well circumscribed. It is often biphasic with both loose 
microcystic and fibrillary areas. The tumor is composed of bipolar cells with long, thin hair-like processes that are GFAP-positive 
and form dense fibrillary meshworks. Rosenthal fibers and eosinophilic granular bodies are 
characteristic findings under microscopy. BRAF mutation is seen in this tumor.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 65-year-old patient presents with headache, seizures, and focal neurological deficit. 
Imaging shows a tumor in the right frontal lobe which crosses the midline and the 
histological section of the resected tumor is shown below. Which of the following molecular 
subtypes does this tumor belong to?
questions.explanation:
The clinical history and histological image are suggestive of primary glioblastoma, IDH - wild 
type. The given histological image shows foci of necrosis with pseudo-palisading of malignant nuclei 
and endothelial cell proliferation, which are characteristic of glioblastoma (previously called 
glioblastoma multiforme). According to the WHO classification of CNS diseases 2016, glioblastomas are classified as follows: 1. Glioblastoma, IDH - wild type: • About 90% of the cases • Primary or de novo glioblastoma • Over 55 years of age 2. Glioblastoma, IDH - mutant type: • About 10% of the cases • Secondary glioblastoma, with a history of prior lower-grade diffuse glioma 1325 
Sold by @itachibot • Arises in younger patients 3. Glioblastoma, NOS, where full IDH evaluation cannot be performed.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 40-year-old patient presents to the OPD with recurrent seizures, headache, and projectile 
vomiting. MRI brain reveals cortical-based heterogeneous tumor with calcification in the 
frontal lobe. The histological section of the resected tumor shows perineuronal satellitosis. 
Which of the following is the most common genetic alteration noted in this tumor?

options.a: Mutation of the isocitrate dehydrogenase genes
options.b: Deletion of portions of chromosomes 1p and 19q

questions.explanation:
The clinical picture is suggestive of oligodendroglioma and the most common genetic alterations 
in oligodendroglioma are mutations of the isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH1 and IDH2) genes. IDH1 and IDH2 gene mutations are seen in upto 90% of oligodendroglioma and they are 
associated with a better prognosis. Deletions of portions of chromosomes 1p and 19q are seen in 
up to 80% of the cases.

questions.question:
Question 5: 1318 
Sold by @itachibot The histological section of an intracranial space-occupying lesion resected from a patient is 
given below. Which of the following tumors shows this pattern?
questions.explanation:
The histological image shows fried egg appearance of cells and is seen in oligodendroglioma. Oligodendroglioma is an infiltrating glioma comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. 
It commonly occurs in the fourth and fifth decades. The lesion is found mostly in the cerebral 
hemispheres, with a predilection for white matter. The tumor is composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular 
chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated 
cytoplasm giving a fried egg appearance. Tumor cells infiltrating the cerebral cortex often collect 
around the neurons (perineuronal satellitosis). Fried eggs in pathology: • Oligodendroglioma on histopathology • Hairy cell leukemia on bone marrow biopsy • Seminoma / Dysgerminoma on light microscopy • Mycoplasma pneumonia fried egg colonies on Eaton agar

Question 7: The spinal MRI of a 30-year-old patient with neurofibromatosis type 2 shows an 
ependymoma. Which of the following is true regarding this tumor?

options.a: Ependymoma is predominantly a spinal tumor
options.b: Ependymoma in children commonly arises from the roof of the fourth ventricle
options.c: CSF seeding of metastasis is commonly seen
options.d: Posterior fossa ependymoma mostly presents with ataxia

questions.explanation:
Ependymoma is predominantly a spinal tumor in adults and is commonly associated 
with neurofibromatosis type 2. CSF dissemination is uncommon despite the relationship of the ependymoma with the ventricular 
system. Posterior fossa ependymoma often manifests with hydrocephalus secondary to progressive

questions.question:
Question 8: The fluorescence in situ hybridization done in a patient with supratentorial ependymoma 
shows positivity for RELA fusion protein. What is the prognosis of this molecular subtype?
questions.explanation: RELA fusion protein positive ependymoma carries the worst prognosis. This highlights the importance of immunohistochemistry in the role of prognosis of ependymoma.

questions.question:
Question 9: An obese patient is being evaluated for recurrent low back pain radiating to both the lower 
limbs. Imaging shows a myxopapillary ependymoma located in the spinal cord. Which of the 
following statements regarding this tumor is incorrect?

options.a: It belongs to WHO grade 2 tumors
options.b: It commonly arises from the filum terminale
options.c: It consists of mucopolysaccharides and a papillary core consisting of blood vessels
options.d: It follows an aggressive clinical course

questions.explanation:
Myxopapillary ependymoma is a slow-growing tumor and do not follow an aggressive clinical 
course. Myxopapillary ependymoma belongs to WHO grade 2 tumors histologically as of the 2021 WHO 
clasiffication of central nervous system tumors. It occurs commonly in the filum terminale of the 
spinal cord and contains papillary elements in a myxoid (acidic and neutral mucopolysaccharides) 
background, admixed with ependymoma-like cells microscopically.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 12-year-old boy presents with complaints of headache, projectile vomiting, and blurring of 
vision. CT scan shows a mass lesion in the posterior cranial fossa. His medical records are 
unremarkable, except for a family history of colon cancer in three of his relatives. What is the 
most probable syndrome that this patient has?
questions.explanation:
1327 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical features and the family history of colon cancer point to the diagnosis of Turcot 
syndrome. Turcot syndrome is a rare hereditary disorder clinically characterized by the occurrence of 
primary tumors of the colon and the central nervous system. Two types of tumors are seen in Turcot syndrome. The first is characterized by childhood 
cerebellar medulloblastoma caused by mutations in the APC gene. The second type is 
characterized by gliomas, particularly glioblastoma multiforme, arising in both children and 
adults and is related to mismatch repair gene mutations. Familial carcinoma syndromes and the common malignancies associated with them: • Gorlin syndrome: Medulloblastoma and multiple early-onset basal cell carcinomas • Lynch syndrome: Gastrointestinal and genito-urinary tumors and rarely gliomas in the brain • Neurofibromatosis: Schwannoma

questions.question:
Question 12: A 40-year-old smoker diagnosed with small cell carcinoma of the lung 1 year back now 
develops seizures, short-term memory loss, and psychiatric symptoms. Which of the following 
paraneoplastic conditions can be attributed to this presentation?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history is suggestive of limbic encephalitis. Limbic encephalitis is characterized by subacute dementia. Histologically, it is characterised by 
perivascular inflammatory cuffs, microglial nodules, neuronal loss, and gliosis evident in the 
anterior and medial portions of the temporal lobe. 1328 
Sold by @itachibot Some of these patients have a circulating ANNA1 antibody (antiHu) that is most commonly associ- 
ated□ with small cell carcinoma of the lung. Another group of these patients have a circulating 
antibody that recognizes the NMDA receptor and cross-reacts with hippocampal neurons.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is diagnosed with a meningioma. which of the following 
growth patterns does the tumor exhibit in the subsequent trimesters of her pregnancy?

options.a: The tumor grows rapidly throughout her pregnancy
options.b: The tumor shrinks throughout her pregnancy
options.c: The tumor grows rapidly in first trimester and shrinks thereafter
options.d: The size of the tumor exhibits no change throughout her pregnancy

questions.explanation: Meningiomas express progesterone receptors and grow more rapidly during pregnancy. Meningiomas are usually slow growing tumors. They show a moderate female predominance. The common sites of involvement of meningiomas are: • The parasagittal aspect of the brain convexity • Dura over the lateral convexity • Wings of the sphenoid • Olfactory groove • Sella turcica • Foramen magnum. Question 14: The MRI of a woman presenting with recurrent headaches is given below. Microscopy of the 
resected tumor shows psammoma bodies and the tumor cells express progesterone receptors. 
Which of the following is the most common cytogenetic abnormality noted in this tumor? 1321 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given MRI showing homogeneously enhancing extra - axial, dural based tumor and the 
microscopic findings are highly suggestive of meningioma. The most common cytogenetic 
abnormality in meningioma is 22q deletion. Meningioma is predominantly a benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura. It arises 
from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. 50% - 60% of the sporadic meningioma harbors 1329 
Sold by @itachibot mutations in the NF2 gene (in chromosome 22q12) resulting in the absence of functional merlin 
protein. In meningioma without NF2 mutations, the most common mutations occur in TNF 
receptor - associated factor 7 (TRAF7).

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following tumors is most commonly associated with meningeal carcinomatosis?
questions.explanation:
Breast carcinoma is commonly associated with meningeal carcinomatosis. Meningeal carcinomatosis presents as tumor nodules studding the surface of the brain, spinal 
cord, and intradural nerve roots.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following types of herniation is characterised by duret hemorrhages?
questions.explanation:
Duret hemorrhages are characteristic of transtentorial herniation. Transtentorial (uncinate, mesial temporal) herniation occurs when the medial aspect of the 
temporal lobe is compressed against the free margin of the tentorium. Progression of 
transtentorial herniation is often accompanied by secondary hemorrhagic lesions in the midbrain 
and pons, termed Duret hemorrhages. These linear or flame - shaped lesions usually occur in the 
midline and paramedian regions and are believed to be due to the distortion or tearing of 
penetrating veins and arteries supplying the upper brainstem. With increasing displacement of the temporal lobe, the third cranial nerve is compromised, 
resulting in pupillary dilation and impairment of ocular movements on the side of the lesion. The 
posterior cerebral artery may also be compressed, resulting in ischemic injury to the territory 
supplied by that vessel, including the primary visual cortex. When the extent of herniation is large enough, the contralateral cerebral peduncle may be 
compressed, resulting in hemiparesis ipsilateral to the side of the herniation. The compression in 
the peduncle in this setting is known as the Kernohan notch.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following structures is involved in tonsillar herniation?
questions.explanation:
Cerebellum is involved in tonsillar herniation. Tonsillar herniation refers to the displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen 
magnum. This pattern of herniation is life-threatening because it causes brainstem compression 
and compromises vital respiratory and cardiac centers in the medulla.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is the most common CNS neoplasm in immunosuppressed patients?
questions.explanation:
Primary central nervous system lymphoma is the most common CNS neoplasm in 
immunosuppressed individuals, including those with AIDS and immunosuppression after 
transplantation. 1330 
Sold by @itachibot The vast majority of primary central nervous system lymphomas are of B-cell origin. Overall, 
primary central nervous system lymphomas are aggressive and have worst outcome. The 
Epstein-Barr virus plays an important role in the pathogenesis of HIV-related primary central 
nervous system lymphoma.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 14-year-old patient presents with bilateral proptosis. The biopsy from the region shows this 
pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and biopsy picture is characteristic of schwannoma. The biopsy specimen in schwannoma shows hypocellular (Antoni B) and hypercellular areas 
(Antoni A). Antoni A area has the nuclei of tumor cells aligned in palisading rows. The 
nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies. The histological section of a schwannoma showing Antoni A, Antoni B and Verocay bodies is given

questions.question: Question 20: CSF spread can occur in patients with all of the following tumors, except:
questions.explanation:
Most of the meningiomas are benign tumors and very rarely metastasize to CSF. The primary intracerebral malignancies that may cause metastases to the subarachnoid space are: • Glioblastoma (GBM) • Anaplastic astrocytoma • Medulloblastoma • Ependymoma • Pineoblastomas • Oligodendroglioma 1331 
Sold by @itachibot Leptomeningeal metastases, also known as carcinomatous meningitis, refer to the spread of 
malignant cells through the CSF space. These cells can originate both in primary CNS tumors 
(e.g. drop-metastases), as well as from distant tumors that have metastasized (hematogenous 
spread). The most common secondary tumors that spread to CSF are breast cancer > lung cancer > 
melanoma > GI malignancies. Contrast MRI is the investigation of choice and shows leptomeningeal enhancement and tumor 
scattered over the brain in a ‘sugar-coated’ manner. 1332 
Sold by @itachibot Peripheral nerves & Neuromuscular pathology
